thread.title: Tougher penalties and integrity body proposed to reform greyhound racing
thread.title_full: Tougher penalties and integrity body proposed to reform greyhound racing

author: Sean Nicholls
title: Tougher penalties and integrity body proposed to reform greyhound racing
text:
Link Greyhound racing in NSW is set to be overseen by a new integrity body. 
RSPCA chairman Steve Coleman – a panel member – said the recommended regime was designed "to ensure that a human can be linked to every greyhound at every part of its life". 
Mr Iemma said a cap "wouldn't be practical at this stage" in the absence of a national approach to greyhound racing numbers. Advertisement 
He said the panel had found the greyhound industry can continue to operate in NSW provided its recommendations are adhered to. 
The changes would ensure that "in essence NSW becomes best practice for greyhound racing and for animal welfare when it comes to the greyhound racing industry". 
Racing minister Paul Toole said the government would respond to the report's 122 recommendations in due course. 
The panel report was commissioned last year by then premier Mike Baird after he backed down on an initial push to close down the industry after concerted industry and media pressure. 
The proposed new three-commissioner Greyhound Welfare and Integrity Commission would act as regulator and operate independent of government. 
It would have "a broad range of investigative powers" to enter and search public and private premises and use in prosecutions evidence gathered by covert surveillance authorised by a court warrant. 
The panel says Greyhound Racing NSW should be stripped of regulatory functions and oversee the sport's commercial operations. 
The regime would introduce "strict controls on euthanasia" and restrictions on small animals such as rabbits and possums that could be used as lures being kept where greyhounds are raced or kept. 
The chief executive of the NSW Greyhound Industry Racing Alliance, Brenton Scott, highlighted a recommendation that the industry should receive a greater share of TAB racing turnover under the inter-code agreement. 
But the NSW Greens rejected the panel's report as "just a political compromise". 
"There is no way any regulator can reform an industry so rotten to the core," said Greens MLC Mehreen Faruqi. Advertisement
